discourse_list.title: What's backing my Dai?: An interactive visualisation

content.content: Hi Maker Community! As @longforwisdom suggested, I’ve created a small visualisation to show what is backing the DAI out there. See it live at https://backeddai.makerdao.network There are some performance issues so please reach out if something doesn’t seem right! (the app sometimes crashes.  ) I’m building a more stable version in the meantime! Thanks to @juan for the help. Preview: image1484×1194 99.8 KB Data source: Beta Program for Vault Tracker API
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post has created an interactive visualization to show what is backing the DAI out there and is asking for feedback from the Maker Community. The post also mentions some performance issues and the author is building a more stable version. The data source is the Beta Program for Vault Tracker API.

content.content: Very cool. Another feature that was sorely missing. Great job!

Really nice work! I think that chart is primed for some MakerDAO presentations to audiences of all knowledge levels. Even for MKR holders it’s a really nice visualization of the potential volatility risk coming from the collateral basket. Would there be a was to take this data and make a “live feed” of what your DAI would be converted to in the event of an emergency shut down? I’m envisioning an updating table here that would show 1 DAI = $0.55 ETH $0.27 USDC…

content.content: I also think it would be valuable to show the USD equivalents of how much collateral you get for each DAI at shutdown. Also the actual amounts would be very cool. If possible it would be great to also show the USD amounts based on the fact that the DAI in the surplus buffer is burned (meaning technically you currently get more than $1 of collateral for your DAI while the surplus buffer is positive) and also reflect that when bad debt is present in the system you will get less than $1 of collateral for your DAI. Also @tadeo this is really cool! Looking forward to seeing how it evolves.

That’s $1.0045 per DAI, which is actually higher than the current market price (which is also the reason having a huge surplus buffer is not necessarily a good idea.)
